question: Should organs be denied to non-donors?

content.source_1: Lavee, J., Ashkenazi, T., Stoler, A., Klein, E., & Steinberg, D. “A new law for allocation of donor organs in Israel.” The Lancet, 2010. Describes Israel’s legislated priority system that gives transplant priority points to registered donors and families who consent to donation; early implementation was associated with increases in donor registration and consent, supporting reciprocity as a way to boost supply.
content.source_2: Singapore Ministry of Health. Human Organ Transplant Act (HOTA). Official policy specifies that individuals who opt out of organ donation receive lower priority for organ transplants, operationalizing a deny/deprioritize-non-donors approach as a fairness measure against free-riding.
content.source_3: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services / Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network (OPTN). Final Rule (42 CFR Part 121) and OPTN Ethics guidance. U.S. allocation must be based on sound medical judgment, urgency, and expected outcomes; using donor registration status to deny or downgrade access would conflict with established allocation principles and governance.
content.source_4: Nuffield Council on Bioethics. “Human bodies: donation for medicine and research.” Report, 2011. Warns that punitive or reciprocity-based priority schemes can unfairly disadvantage people medically ineligible to donate or with conscientious/religious objections, risk eroding altruism and public trust, and should not be used to deny care.
content.source_5: Kessler, J. B., & Roth, A. E. “Organ Allocation Policy and the Decision to Register as an Organ Donor.” American Economic Review, 2012. Experimental and field evidence shows donor-priority rules can increase registration, but effects depend on design and may not translate into higher actual donation if other barriers (e.g., family veto, system capacity) persist.
